statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Santa Clara 86, Stanford 76
article.story: SANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- Dick Davey has been coaching long enough to know that a 58-point half doesn't happen every day. Santa Clara needed such a performance to get its second upset win in two weeks. Travis Niesen had career highs of 31 points and 11 rebounds for his second career double-double, and the Broncos ended an eight-game losing streak against Stanford with an 86-76 victory Sunday night. "The second half was as good offensively as we've played in a long time," said Davey, Santa Clara's 13th-year coach. Dan Grunfeld scored a career-high 26 points and Rob Little added 15 for Stanford, which hadn't lost to Santa Clara since the 1989-90 season. Chris Hernandez had 10 points and eight assists. The cold-shooting Cardinal played a sloppy game and had trouble controlling loose balls. They were held without a field goal for more than five minutes in the second half and shot 37.5 percent. "We can't always go out there and drift and expect talent to lift us up," Grunfeld said. "We've been used to being the hunted. We have to be the hunter." For the Broncos (4-2), it was their second big win in three games -- they beat North Carolina by 11 points at the Pete Newell Challenge on Nov. 19. Niesen celebrated this one in a similar manner: pumping his fist and yelling with the home crowd. The Broncos hoped to rebound quickly from their 71-65 loss at Pacific last Tuesday, and they did. "It's good to get a good effort like we had against North Carolina," Niesen said. "It was really important." Santa Clara used a 12-3 spurt midway through the second half to build a 52-45 lead with 9:50 left -- a run that included a goaltending call against Stanford's Matt Haryasz that gave Jordan Legge two points. Haryasz finished with nine points and 10 rebounds before fouling out with 2:02 left. The Broncos put the final touches on the victory when Doron Perkins threw an alley-oop to Tristan Parham for a dunk with 1:40 left. Perkins finished with 12 points and four assists. "We definitely have to improve our ability to rebound and our ability to defend," first-year Stanford coach Trent Johnson said. "We have been outrebounded in four of the five games. It was evident to me that Santa Clara was the aggressor tonight. Our lack of toughness and inability to be aggressive is a concern." Stanford (2-3) finished sixth in the eight-team Maui Invitational last week and never looked completely comfortable in the first meeting between these teams since the championship game of the Cable Car Classic in 2000, won 78-63 by the Cardinal. Stanford, 30-2 last season and ranked No. 1 in the nation, needed overtime to beat its last West Coast Conference opponent, a 93-83 win over San Francisco in the Pete Newell Challenge. The Cardinal started the game 0-for-12 and didn't get a field goal until Little's hook shot at the 11:59 mark of the first half. They shot 31 percent in the first half to 40 percent for the Broncos, but still led Santa Clara 29-28 at the break. Stanford now takes a two-week break for finals and won't play again until Dec. 11 at Michigan State. The Cardinal play Dec. 13 at Denver before returning home to make their debut in the Maples Pavilion, which underwent a $30 million facelift over the past nine months.
